results.title: Living with disaster: stories and experiences from disasters
results.brief_description: ‘Living with disaster’ is a major project by ACMI in collaboration with the Attorney General’s Department through its Emergency Management division and the CFA, in order to capture stories of young people who have survived natural disasters.

results.title: Fisherman's fall
results.creator_credit: Robert Nichol, Peter Jones and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: One of Canada’s best known fly-fishermen, essayist Roderick Haig-Brown, demonstrates the art of salmon fishing in the Campbell River of northern Vancouver Island. The film, like the fisherman, has eyes for more than the river’s surface. The camera looks below, showing what the fish sees and the fisherman senses. A film of solitude and of harmony with nature. (Awards: Toronto; Detroit; Novi Sad)

results.title: Fish and chips cooking library. - Volume 1.
results.brief_description: Simple recipes garnished with humour and a smattering of hints and tips are demonstrated by Peter Doyle of the Sydney restaurant family. He shows you everything you need to know about how to make delicious seafood meals, including how to cook a fish in your dishwasher. The video is accompanied by a recipe booklet which also includes charts which show you which fish to substitute for another, and when particular fish are in season. The video is also time coded so that you can find the recipe you want, quickly and easily.

results.title: First winter
results.creator_credit: John Smith, Roman Kroitor, Sam Grana and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: This historical drama features the first winter spent in Canada by a family of Irish immigrants deep in the Ottawa Valley. The year is 1830. Because the father is working in a logging camp, the mother has sole charge of the family. Sickness overtakes her and she dies. The children are left on their own to survive. The film graphically illustrates the enormous hardships endured by the first settlers who had to cope with a climate they were unfamiliar with. Filmed in Algonquin Park.
results.creator_credit_for_label: John Smith, Roman Kroitor, Sam Grana and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: First Tuesday: four hours in My Lai [anatomy of a massacre]
results.creator_credit: Kevin Sim, Michael Bilton and Yorkshire Television
results.brief_description: Tells the story of the massacre of villagers (mostly women and children), by U.S. troops at the Vietnamese village of My Lai on March 16, 1968. Survivors, both villagers and soldiers, speak of their experiences, memories and how they have coped since.

results.title: First impressions: a journey to the Pilbara, Western Austral
results.creator_credit: David Rapsey, Paul Barron, Paul D. Barron and Perth Institute of Film and Television
results.brief_description: Documents the ideas, stages and techniques involved in the creation of German-born Jorg Schmeisser’s etchings in the north west of Western Australia and their final execution in his studio in Canberra. The creative process is as much about Jorg’s relationship to the etching plate as with his interaction with the landscape.
results.title_for_label: First impressions: a journey to the Pilbara, Western Austral

results.title: First days (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Ron Saunders, Lesley Hammond and Slater Film Productions
results.brief_description: Looks at a school is South Australia where a policy of continual admission for five year olds is in operation. Shows the way in which the parents and the new child are put at ease by the principal and class. Indicates the sorts of adjustments required from both the new student and the teachers. Also looks at vertical and small groups, open plan classrooms and parental involvement. Written by Terry Jennings.

results.title: Fire in the east: a portrait of Robert Frank [NTSC]
results.creator_credit: Amy Brookman, Philip Brookman, Anne Wilkes Tucker, Paul Yeager, KUHT-TV (Television station : Houston, Tex.) and Museum of Fine Arts, Houston
results.brief_description: Swiss-born photographer renowned for capturing the “raw stuff of life”, Robert Frank moved to the United States in 1953 and soon found himself a part of the Beat Generation along with other artists, poets, writers and photographers. This documentary presents a biographical portrait of Frank and the enormous influence his work has had on contemporary photography. In 1955 he was awarded a Guggenheim Fellowship and spent two years travelling across America photographing all that encompasses the American way of life, resulting in the publication in 1958 of an extraordinary photo-journal titled “The Americans” (introduction written by his friend Jack Kerouac). By 1959 Frank was experimenting with filmmaking producing his first film “Pull my daisy” which featured Allen Ginsberg and Gregory Corso, and script and voiceover by Jack Kerouac. Frank continued to make films well into the 60s including “Me and my brother” and “Conversations in Vermont”. By the 1970s he had moved to Canada and began to divide his energies between film, video and photography producing an amazing array of work - forever, it seems, in search of the truth “out there”. This award-winning documentary features Frank’s photographs, excerpts from his films, and interviews with many of his collaborators and contemporaries, including Rudy Wurlitzer (writer), Louis Faurer (photographer), Elliott Erwitt (photographer), Emile de Antonio (filmmaker), June Leaf (artist) and Allen Ginsberg (poet). Contains some b&w images and archival footage. Narrated by Philip Brookman.

results.title: Fire and ice [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Ralph Bakshi, Frank Frazetta and Polyc International
results.brief_description: This animated feature is set in a mythical Ice Age, where, Juliana, a powerful Queen of the North, seeks to gain control the rest of the realm. In this realm also resides the good King, Jarol, who lives in his fortress of fire and his sworn enemy, evil ice Lord Nekron, who lives with his army of subhumans amongst the glaciers. Nekron uses his powers of sorcery to create havoc and orders the subhumans to kidnap Jarol’s daughter. Thus a war is waged between fire and ice in a desperate battle for survival. Jarol, with help from the warrior hero Darkwolf must save mankind from the apocalyptic icy grave that awaits them if evil is to reign. Featuring the voices of Stephen Mendel, Maggie Roswell, Leo V. Gordon and Steve Sandor. Director Ralph Bakshi is best known for his animated adult feature “Fritz the cat”.
